title: Read This Before You Panic About Your Penetration Report
partialText: Security tools speak in volumes of automated findings. Business leaders speak in risk, cost, and “should I be worried right now?’ That gap is where the panic starts.

title: When Senior Teams Stop Debugging Their Decisions
partialText: Senior teams often stop debugging their decisions once alignment seems achieved, mistaking silence for clarity and shared understanding. This "interpretive drift" occurs when confidence replaces interrogation, compressing decision-making processes and hiding assumptions. The real risk isn’t misalignment but the invisible divergence of mental models, leading to downstream failures. Experience and efficiency paradoxically make senior teams more vulnerable to this, as they rely on intuition and compressed communication, reducing friction that tests assumptions. The solution lies in making thinking visible, even when decisions feel obvious, to prevent systemic drift.

title: Are Niche Markets the Future of Crypto Presales?
partialText: Analysis of why crypto presales targeting niche markets like pet care and local payments show better survival rates than broad general-purpose projects. Editorial perspective on market trends and investor evaluation criteria.

title: I Tried to Trick 7 AI Models With Fake Facts, but They Didn’t Fall for It
partialText: I tested seven models available through Together AI's API: Llama-4-Maverick, GPT-OSS, Qwen3-Next, GLM-5, Kimi-K2.5 and Mistral-Small. Each model received the same prompt: verify the statement and respond with a verdict (true/false), confidence level (low/medium/high), and brief explanation. Temperature was set to 0 for consistency.

title: Tape Isn’t Slow, Pipelines Are
partialText: This article explains how to run multiple tape libraries and media pools like adults. It covers VSN-driven recalls, mount/seek realities, drive sharing, sane concurrency, and queue hygiene.

title: AI Coding Tip 007 - Protect Your AI Agents from Malicious Skills
partialText: AI coding assistants with installable “skills” introduce a new software supply chain risk: malicious plugins that can access secrets, execute arbitrary code, and expose infrastructure. Developers should treat agent skills like untrusted executable code—run them in isolated environments, review source files, restrict permissions, and bind services locally to reduce attack surface and prevent credential theft.

title: You'll Own Nothing and Be Happy
partialText: Welcome to 2026! That’ll be $12.99 + tax, charged monthly, or you could get an annual subscription for $120 + tax for a whole 22% off!

title: Public Masterpiece Announces PMT Chain, A Layer 1 Built for the Real-World Asset Economy
partialText: Public Masterpiece is a Cyprus-based real-world asset tokenization company. The company has announced PMT Chain, its own purpose-built Layer 1 blockchain. PMT has reportedly increased in price by 75%, outperforming 86% of the top 100 crypto assets, including Bitcoin.

title: AlphaTON Capital Deploys 504 NVIDIA Blackwell B200 GPUs to Power Telegram’s AI Infrastructure
partialText: AlphaTON Capital Corp signed a $30M AI compute lease to deploy 504 NVIDIA Blackwell B200 GPUs in Canada, scaling infrastructure for Telegram’s 1B-user ecosystem. The rollout is expected to generate $1.2M–$1.45M monthly, with total projected revenue of $3.1M once 1,080 GPUs are online. Positioned as privacy-centric, sovereign AI infrastructure, the expansion reflects surging demand for confidential compute outside Big Tech hyperscalers.

title: Cybersecurity Excellence Awards Reveal Nomination Shift From AI Hype To Governance Execution
partialText: Early nomination insights from the 2026 program highlight a shift in vendor emphasis from broad AI positioning toward governance frameworks, identity architecture, and measurable accountability. Autonomous systems are moving from pilot to production faster than governance frameworks can keep pace.

title: How to Future-Proof Your Technical Documentation for AI and RAG Systems
partialText: Traditional documentation was built for human readers, but modern AI systems consume text in isolated chunks, creating context loss and retrieval failures. To support Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), technical writers must adopt explicit, self-contained language, semantically rich structures, qualified headings, metadata tagging, and automated linting. AI-ready documentation is no longer optional; it is an architectural discipline.

title: Centrifuge & Pharos Partner to Advance Onchain Distribution as Tokenized RWAs Cross $36 Billion
partialText: Centrifuge and Pharos have announced a partnership to build shared distribution infrastructure for institutional-grade tokenized assets including U.S. Treasuries and AAA-rated credit products. The deal targets a specific bottleneck: most tokenized assets sit idle after issuance because distribution rails do not exist at scale. With the tokenized RWA market crossing $36 billion and projected to hit $18.9 trillion by 2033, the partnership is a bet that infrastructure, not issuance, is the real constraint.

title: The Ghost in the Warehouse: How to Solve Schema Drift in Analytical AI Agents
partialText: The "Monday Morning Problem" is a familiar nightmare for teams deploying analytical AI. In the world of conversational AI for analytics, **schema drift** is the final boss. This article presents a battle-tested framework for building a memory system that survives the chaos of a constantly evolving database.

title: Identity Discontinuity in Multi-Bank FX Systems
partialText: Multi-bank FX reconciliation failures are rarely caused by missing data or inadequate tooling. They emerge when independently optimized systems disagree on trade identity across execution, settlement, accounting, and reporting layers. Industry standards improve message structure but do not enforce lifecycle-wide identity continuity. Deterministic reconciliation requires treating identity as a system invariant rather than as metadata inferred through tolerance rules.

title: Why Modern QA Teams Are Betting on Gen AI Testing
partialText: Generative AI is an AI LLM model capable of generating novel and valuable outputs, such as test cases or test data, without explicit human instruction. Modern QA teams rely on AI to handle rapid UI changes, microservices complexity, and accelerated release cycles. Generative AI improves test coverage, consistency, and feedback speed while reducing manual effort and maintenance.

title: Swift Network Error Handling: A Complete Guide to a Production-Ready Layer
partialText: In a previous article, we explored how to construct a robust, abstract network layer using**Clean Architecture**. In this article, I explain how to categorize HTTP status codes into specific enums. This approach ensures that our logic is both type-safe and highly readable.

title: OpenClaw’s 85,000 GitHub Stars Hide a Security Nightmare, Researchers Warn
partialText: AI agents can automate powerful tasks, but poor security design can expose APIs, control panels, credentials, and internal systems. Attackers can exploit misconfigured permissions, unsafe tool integrations, and leaked tokens to gain unauthorized access. To stay secure, organizations must apply least-privilege access, protect secrets, monitor agent activity, validate inputs, and treat AI agents like privileged infrastructure, not simple assistants.

title: Designing Enterprise-Grade Agentic AI Systems on AWS
partialText: Prototype AI agents are easy. Operating them at scale is not. This article outlines a production-focused architecture for AWS agent workflows—covering model selection, orchestration, governance, observability, cost controls, and vector retrieval reliability. By structuring decisions across models, frameworks, and protocols, teams can turn promising pilots into stable, auditable, and scalable enterprise systems.

title: Check Point Doubles Down on Unified Security with Rotate Deal as AI-Driven Attacks Target Daily Work
partialText: Check Point has acquired Israeli startup Rotate to build a new Workspace Security division. The deal signals a structural shift in how enterprise security gets delivered, with Check Point betting that protecting fragmented digital workspaces requires a unified protection layer rather than patching individual tools.

title: A Breach in Uzbekistan’s Digital Infrastructure Exposes the Risks of Rapid E-Government Expansion
partialText: In January 2026, cyberattacks targeting three Uzbek government systems led to the exposure of roughly 60,000 data records — far fewer than early claims of 15 million. Authorities quickly launched an investigation, suspended online microcredit issuance, and reinforced authentication systems. The incident highlights the risks of centralized OAuth infrastructure amid rapid digital transformation and rising cybercrime across Central Asia, where advanced threat groups like Bloody Wolf are actively targeting state and financial systems.
